question_details.title: Will JetBlue announce that it has acquired Spirit Airlines before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2023-04-01 02:09:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/15410). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

On July 28, 2022, JetBlue and Spirit Airlines [announced](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1158463/000119312522204208/d319514dex991.htm) that their boards of directors had approved a merger between the two companies through which JetBlue would acquire Spirit for $33.50 a share, at an enterprise value of $7.6 billion, and following the merger would eventually operate as a single airline under the JetBlue name and be the 5th largest airline in the United States. The airlines [planned](https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/28/business/jetblue-spirit-merger.html) to complete the transaction in the first half of 2024.  On October 19, 2022 Spirit's shareholders [approved](https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1498710/000149871022000336/a221019stockholderapprov.htm) the deal. 

On March 7, 2023, the US Department of Justice [announced](https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/justice-department-sues-block-jetblue-s-proposed-acquisition-spirit) an antitrust lawsuit to block the acquisition on the grounds that it would harm consumers by eliminating an ultra-low-cost carrier, which would result in, according to the DOJ, "raising costs for the flying public and harming cost-conscious fliers most acutely." JetBlue and Spirit [announced](https://investor.jetblue.com/news/news-details/2023/JetBlue-and-Spirit-Will-Continue-to-Advance-Plan-to-Create-Compelling-National-Low-Fare-Challenger-to-the-Dominant-U.S.-Carriers/default.aspx) that they would "vigorously defend"  against the DOJ's suit, arguing that the post-merger JetBlue would be a stronger and more competitive airline against the legacy carriers.

According to [research](https://www.mckinsey.com/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/done-deal-why-many-large-transactions-fail-to-cross-the-finish-line) by McKinsey, in any given year about 10% of large M&A transactions are cancelled, with larger combinations being more likely to be cancelled. The 2nd most common reason for mergers to be terminated is for regulatory or antitrust concerns. A recent [legal analysis](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2022/11/07/doj-sees-mixed-results-in-litigation-focused-antitrust-strategy/?slreturn=20230209091925) finds the DOJ under the Biden Administration to have a more expansive view of antitrust and a willingness to go to trial even when facing difficult cases. This has resulted in a string of defeats but also recent victories such as blocking the acquisition of Simon & Schuster by Penguin Random House.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question resolves as **Yes** based on either of two events happening:

1. A JetBlue press release stating that it has completed its acquisition of Spirit Airlines.
2. An SEC filing by JetBlue stating that the deal has been completed. 

This question resolves as **No** immediately upon an announcement (either through press release or an SEC filing) by JetBlue stating that the acquisition deal has been terminated. Otherwise if no deal has been completed before January 1, 2026, this resolves as **No**

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Spirit Airlines Restructures Again, Plans to Cut Jobs and Reduce Capacity**
Spirit Airlines, after emerging from its first bankruptcy in early 2025, is announcing a second restructuring that will cut jobs and reduce flight capacity. According to a memo from CEO Dave Davis cited by CNBC, the carrier will trim its November flight schedule, expecting a roughly 25% drop in capacity this year as it "optimises" its network for stronger markets. Davis said, '这些评估将不可避免地影响我们团队的规模，因为我们正在成为一家更高效的航空公司。' He added that negotiations with union leaders will take place in the coming weeks. The airline has already suspended and demoted hundreds of pilots, and some cabin crew are on unpaid leave. In the March‑June period, Spirit posted a $257 million loss, and after a failed merger with JetBlue, it faces higher costs, weak U.S. travel demand and intense competition. The story was reported by CNBC and published by the Malaysian Oriental Daily (东方网).
Original language: zh
Publish date: September 18, 2025 04:57 AM
Source:[東方網 馬來西亞東方日報](https://www.orientaldaily.com.my/news/business/2025/09/18/762371)

**Spirit Airlines to Cut Jobs and Reduce Flights Amid Second Restructuring in 2025 - EconoTimes**
Spirit Airlines announced a second restructuring for 2025 that will cut about 25% of its flight capacity and lead to significant job losses. Chief Executive Dave Davis explained that the changes aim to 'optimize' the carrier’s network by concentrating on stronger markets, but acknowledged that the evaluations will inevitably affect staffing levels, with union leaders to be consulted in the coming weeks. The move follows earlier capacity reductions from March to June and follows the airline’s exit from its first bankruptcy. Spirit has already implemented furloughs, demotions for hundreds of pilots, and unpaid leave for many flight attendants. Financially, the airline reported a $257 million loss for the March‑June period, amid higher operating costs, softer U.S. travel demand, and increased competition, especially after a failed merger with JetBlue Airways. Analysts view the aggressive restructuring as a response to the volatile budget‑airline environment, hoping that reduced routes and tighter operations will help restore profitability.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 18, 2025 03:37 AM
Source:[EconoTimes](https://econotimes.com/Spirit-Airlines-to-Cut-Jobs-and-Reduce-Flights-Amid-Second-Restructuring-in-2025-1720945)

**United CEO declares death of low-cost flights**
United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby sparked controversy on September 10, 2025, when he predicted the collapse of Spirit Airlines and declared the era of ultra‑low‑cost flying was ending. Kirby said, 'Because I'm good at math,' to explain why he believes Spirit will fail, during a Q&A at the Airline Passenger Experience Association conference in Long Beach, California. He has long criticized discount carriers for relying on growth that he says is unsustainable, and he warned that a model that 'predicated on'screw the customer' is doomed. Kirby also attacked Spirit’s business model at a separate event in Washington, DC, prompting backlash from Spirit’s social media, where a post read, 'Scott is finally right about something -- it is all about customers.'

Spirit Airlines filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in August 2024 for the second time in a year, after failing to make significant changes during its first attempt. The airline, based in Florida and known for its bright yellow planes, emerged from bankruptcy in March 2024 after creditors approved a restructuring plan that wiped out all existing shares. Spirit now carries $2.4 billion in long‑term debt, most due in 2030, and reported a negative free cash flow of $1 billion at the end of the second quarter. In the same period, Spirit furloughed 270 pilots and demoted another 140 to cut costs.

Spirit had previously sought a merger with Frontier Airlines in 2022, but JetBlue Airways outbid Frontier and the deal was later blocked by the Department of Justice for violating antitrust laws. The airline has struggled with losses and declining revenue since the pandemic and has not posted an annual profit since before the pandemic. Kirby’s comments reflect United’s broader criticism of the ultra‑low‑cost model, which includes carriers such as Frontier, Sun Country, Southwest, JetBlue and Allegiant, but United claims these competitors are more customer‑friendly.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 17, 2025 01:01 PM
Source:[Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-15107325/United-CEO-declares-death-low-cost-flights.html)

**United Airlines CEO gives major update on bid to purchase struggling rival**
United Airlines CEO Scott Kirby confirmed on Tuesday that United will not acquire assets from Spirit Airlines, dismissing speculation that United might rescue the bankrupt carrier.  'It's not in our wheelhouse,' Kirby told Reuters, explaining that each Spirit plane would need roughly $15 million in modifications to meet United's standards and that Spirit's slots—such as those at Fort Lauderdale—lack sufficient gates for United's operations.  United has begun operating new flights in markets where Spirit previously flew, giving customers alternatives if Spirit ceases service.  In late August 2025, Frontier Airlines announced a similar strategy, adding 20 new routes in former Spirit markets; Deutsche Bank analysts said Frontier profited from Spirit's bankruptcy.  Both United and Frontier face challenges from customer preference for premium options, an oversupply of domestic flights, and rising labor costs.  Spirit filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in August, its second filing within a year; after the filing, Spirit cut routes and staff, creating opportunities for rivals.  Kirby noted that 'If I dig deeper into it and I look at every airline that's not named United Airlines or Delta Airlines, I can find at every single one of them, a double‑digit percentage of their route network that loses money,' and argued that struggling airlines must 'stop flying to places that lose money.'  JetBlue had negotiated a merger with Spirit but abandoned the plan in March 2024.  Spirit will officially drop all routes to 11 airports from October 2.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 16, 2025 09:17 PM
Source:[The US Sun](https://www.the-sun.com/travel/15199264/scott-kirby-united-airlines-spirit-bankruptcy-buy/)

**Spirit Airlines Announces Flight Cuts and Layoffs Amid Second Bankruptcy**
Spirit Airlines CEO Dave Davis announced on 17 September 2025 that the carrier will cut 25 % of its flights in November and reduce its route network by 11 destinations, canceling a 12th planned route. The airline is also negotiating with suppliers and aircraft lessors to reassess its fleet size, a move that will affect staffing levels. Davis said the company will keep employees informed throughout the process and will meet union leaders in the coming weeks. Spirit, which filed for bankruptcy twice in 2024, has already placed hundreds of pilots on unpaid leave and offered voluntary unpaid leave to cabin crew. Earlier in September, the airline cut 11 routes and cancelled a 12th; United, Frontier and JetBlue have launched new services to attract Spirit passengers. The American Federation of Airworkers said the latest bankruptcy poses greater challenges than the first. Spirit has historically relied on high‑density seating and low operating costs. Since emerging from bankruptcy in March, the airline has not made major reforms, converting about $800 million of creditor debt into equity, and remains under financial pressure, reporting a loss of $257 million from March 13 to end‑June 2025. The company plans to keep employees updated as adjustments are made. The airline’s spokesperson said, '我们已与工会讨论，评估航线及机队调整对员工的影响，随着讨论进展，我们将提供更多后续信息。'
Original language: zh
Publish date: September 18, 2025 06:22 AM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/gb/25/9/18/n14597096.htm)

**Spirit Airlines Announces Flight Cuts and Expanded Layoffs**
Spirit Airlines CEO Dave Davis announced on 17 September 2025 that the carrier will cut 25 % of its flights in November and will lay off staff as part of a broader restructuring. The company is revising its route map, planning a November timetable, and negotiating with suppliers and aircraft lessors to assess fleet size. **United Airlines and JetBlue Launch 'Blue Sky' Partnership**
United Airlines and JetBlue Airways have announced a strategic partnership called 'Blue Sky' to offer passengers greater flexibility in booking and access to a wider network. This collaboration allows travelers to book flights on both airlines' websites and accumulate or redeem loyalty points interchangeably. Subject to regulatory approval, some aspects of the partnership may begin as early as autumn 2025. United Airlines will have up to seven daily slots at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK) starting from 2027, marking its return to JFK after leaving in 2022. JetBlue will receive additional time slots at Newark Liberty International Airport, strengthening its presence at United's East Coast hub. United Airlines' CEO, Scott Kirby, has described the move as a mistake. The airline briefly returned to JFK in 2021 due to a decrease in traffic at the airport caused by COVID-19. United had to leave JFK in 2022 because it was unable to secure long-term slot allocations. The partnership highlights the integration of loyalty programs, allowing members of United's MileagePlus and JetBlue's TrueBlue to accumulate and redeem points on both airlines. Passengers with elite status can enjoy reciprocal benefits, including upgrades and flexibility in changing flights. The loyalty programs of airlines are becoming increasingly important revenue streams. During the COVID-19 pandemic, US airlines used these programs to generate revenue and raise funds. In 2023, United Airlines' loyalty program revenue reached $3.49 billion, a 10% increase from the previous year. The airline will increase lounge access fees to $1,400 starting from March 2025. Both airlines will maintain independent control over their flight operations, including schedules and prices. This approach distinguishes the 'Blue Sky' alliance from JetBlue's previous Northeast Alliance with American Airlines, which was dissolved in 2023 due to antitrust concerns. This is not the only setback United Airlines has faced regarding a collaboration. In 2024, a US federal judge blocked United Airlines' proposal to acquire low-cost carrier Spirit, citing that the deal would remove a low-cost carrier from the market. The implications of this partnership are strategic for both airlines. For United Airlines, it facilitates a strategic return to JFK, resolving previous operational issues at Newark and expanding its presence in the competitive New York market. JetBlue, on the other hand, gains greater access to Newark, aligning with its focus on leisure travel on the East Coast and efforts to overcome post-pandemic profitability challenges. In the last nine quarters, JetBlue has reported a profit only in two of them. The 'Blue Sky' alliance represents a significant step towards improving passenger comfort and expanding network connectivity for both United Airlines and JetBlue. While the partnership awaits regulatory approval, travelers can expect a more integrated and flexible flying experience in the future.

summary: All experts unanimously forecast an extremely low probability (1%) that JetBlue will announce it has acquired Spirit Airlines before 2026. Their reasoning is anchored in the fact that the JetBlue-Spirit merger was formally abandoned in March 2024 following a federal antitrust block and judicial decision in January 2024. Since then, Spirit Airlines has entered bankruptcy twice and is undergoing severe financial distress, downsizing, and restructuring, with competitors like United and Frontier moving to capture Spirit's market share and assets but not pursuing acquisition. JetBlue has shifted focus to partnerships (notably with United), and there has been no indication of renewed negotiations or intentions to revive the deal. The regulatory and antitrust climate remains highly unfavorable to large airline mergers, especially those that reduce competition among ultra-low-cost carriers. Experts consistently note the historical base rate for previously blocked/abandoned airline mergers being completed within such a tight window is close to zero, especially with ongoing bankruptcy and clear industry signaling that all parties have moved on. Only a dramatic and currently unforeseen regulatory, political, or financial shock could produce a different outcome. All expert scenarios for a 'Yes' require extremely unlikely events, while the 'No' outcome aligns with the ongoing news, public statements, competitor actions, and regulatory precedent.
